sub_title: Business Development at CIBA Bio Jet Fuel
summary:
I'm a resourceful, undaunted, inter-cultural planner and negotiator. As I have lived in two countries working in four languages, I'm able to draw on my international experience and education to achieve a meeting of minds and to establish trust. In fact, it's what I thrive on.

I'm equally at home in academic, prestigious and disadvantaged environments. For me, it's about using my talents to bring people together. For me, language is a means to an end, not an end in itself. Although I'm well qualified academically in translation, my strengths are in analysis and resolution.

projects.title: After-school care for IDP children — Breath Care for Kids
projects.description: Separately from my work with the Georgian Embassy in The Hague, I conceptualised, managed and coordinated a project to provide free after-school facilities for internally displaced children in Georgia. Breath Care for Kids funded the project.

contributors.headline: Business Development at CIBA Bio Jet Fuel

projects.title: Social Projects Coordinator — Georgian Embassy
projects.description:
I co-initiated and was one of the co-ordinators for three substantial projects under the auspices of the Georgian Embassy in The Hague:

1. “Expatriate Children for Refugee Children in Georgia”: following the 2008 war in Georgia, the Embassy was keen to gain support for the displaced children at a refugee camp, by securing donations, gifts and practical support from Georgians in the Netherlands. I designed this project together with a colleague, created its content and was one of its organisers.

2. Raising awareness of the shifting barbed-wire borders being installed on Georgian territory by Russia: also as a consequence of the 2008 war, Georgia found itself facing (and still does) the ongoing encroachment of the Russian "border", causing a creeping loss of territory and splitting farms and villages in half. Again, in this case I was the content creator and organiser. We installed symbolic barbed wire in the main hall in the Embassy and exhibited photographs of the affected area of Georgia.

3. A charity fundraising event to gain support for Tbilisi Zoo after its devastating flooding.

contributors.headline: Business Development at CIBA Bio Jet Fuel

projects.title: ICF Apeldoorn — Neighborhood Encounters for Refugees
projects.description: I led a team of volunteers planning all the logistics for a series of neighborhood encounters among refugees in Apeldoorn. The team cooked for the refugees, and I ensured that we had enough people and resources for each encounter.

contributors.headline: Business Development at CIBA Bio Jet Fuel

courses.name: Network organisations for Peace Building and Conflict Prevention

profile_positions.description:
I'm someone who loves community and making people feel valued and comfortable. I've been a cultural bridge-builder most of my life, and certainly since I emigrated from my native country. In my current role, I get to do all those good things.

This work involves spanning the gap between different backgrounds in a culturally diverse community, so it's often demanding and can be sensitive work. I administer the church's programmes and assist in organising its events, manage volunteers when needed, and undertake general office management.

This is a thrilling job to be in, as it lets me be of service to people from diverse backgrounds and to put into practice what I've learned over my years in the Netherlands about getting to grips with a new environment, finding rootedness, feeling valued and having a sense of purpose and letting people find an outlet for their talents. I also get to use my languages.
profile_positions.title: Administration Manager

profile_positions.description:
Translation is one of the world's most essential professions, and interpreting (the spoken equivalent of translation) is another. I have had the joy of working in this field professionally since I graduated from that field at Georgia's best university.

It's not often appreciated in the West how essential it is to the life of small nations to be able to communicate accurately across borders. For countries like Georgia, with a small population and a unique language, translation and interpreting is a way of life and a valued skill so that we can share our experiences and needs across borders. Otherwise, our businesses and public services would suffer greatly from isolation. For this reason, I feel a lifelong commitment to provide accurate translations of important documents and to interpret well in key encounters between Georgians and foreigners.

I have translated in various combinations between the four languages that I speak natively or near-natively: Georgian, Russian, Dutch and English. My commissions have included local government (Municipality of Beverwijk), national government (Georgian Embassy in the Netherlands), national media (NTR News), law firms (BOHLER), and medical practices (Amsterdam Medical Centre).
profile_positions.title: Translator/ Interpreter

profile_positions.description:
There are few more thrilling opportunities than to help represent your native country in the country where you have come to live. I had the privilege of working for the Georgian Ambassador as an assistant on Dutch-related issues, and worked as an administrative manager and in the Embassy's public relations.

For one thing, in this job I was putting my qualifications and abilities in translation to good use (between four languages: Russian, Georgian, Dutch and English). I researched, translated and analysed information regarding Georgia in the Netherlands for the Ambassador and for his head office, the Georgian Ministry of Foreign Affairs.

This often involved rapid responses to fake news and resulted in high-impact pieces to correct the record in the Dutch press. In the other direction, my job involved me facilitating the work of the Georgian Consul-General at the Embassy when she was having trouble contacting the right person in Dutch officialdom in order to serve Georgian citizens in the Netherlands.

I also undertook some fulfilling and valuable social projects during this time (see under Accomplishments below).

I managed the Embassy’s online presence during these years.
profile_positions.title: Assistant to the Ambassador

profile_positions.description: Building on my experience at Nassau (see below), I went on to the more demanding job of teaching third- and fourth-year secondary students in the academically highest streams of Dutch schooling, Gymnasium and Athenaeum. This was a thrilling opportunity to develop promising young minds and to finesse my Dutch to a high level.
profile_positions.title: Teacher of English

profile_positions.description: While still a student in the Netherlands, and already having quite some experience of teaching in Georgia (I had an academic qualification in teaching too), I decided that a good use of my talents would be teaching for the introductory year of Dutch secondary school (HAVO 1). I always enjoy being around young people and felt that this way, I was putting something of value back into the society that had welcomed me in.
profile_positions.title: Teacher of English

volunteer_experiences.description: Teacher of Georgian Language to Georgian expatriate children at Sunday school run by the Georgian Embassy.

• Fundraising, publicity and promotion of the organisation.
• Raised awareness in the Netherlands.
• Made arrangements for children’s summer camps.
• Arranged and ordered the financial administration.
• Mediated between the donors and the organisation management.
